awd_titl_txt: NSF RUI: The Hadronization of the Omega and F1 Mesons at Jefferson Lab
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is a successful theory of the strong interaction, the force that binds the nucleus.  It can account for the types of quarks and the nuclear charges in the sub-structure of nuclear particles called hadrons.  The greatest successes of QCD occur at high energies.  At lower energies, the quarks clump together due to a phenomenon known as confinement.  The simple picture is that of stationary quarks held by strings of nuclear fields.  If a quark is extracted from a hadron, the string stretches and pulls a quark-antiquark pair from the vacuum leading to hadron production.  However, nature is more complicated with dynamical quarks bound in hadrons.  More experimental information is needed to explain the process of hadron formation.  This project is a study of the formation of two hadrons, the omega and f1 mesons.  These particles are produced in reactions where a high-energy electron is scattered from nuclei of deuterium, carbon, iron, and lead.  The experiments are conducted at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (TJNAF) in Newport News, VA.   The Canisius College Medium Energy Nuclear Physics group, led by Dr. Michael Wood, is actively involved at TJNAF.  The group will mine the data from an experiment that has already taken place for these mesons.  In addition, the group is preparing for a follow-up experiment, which will extend the earlier research to higher beam energy.  The undergraduate students involved in the project will gain valuable experience in mining large data sets and develop analysis skills.

The process of hadronization is characterized by two distinct time periods, the propagation time and the formation time.  The Canisius College Medium Energy Nuclear Physics (CMENP) group seeks to understand the time frame for a free quark to couple with other quarks (propagation) and to stabilize its color field (formation).  Nuclei of different sizes are used to extract these times.   The width of the transverse momentum-squared (p2T) varies for nuclei with different sizes, with a greater broadening being associated with a longer propagation time.  This project is part of a larger program at Jefferson Lab (JLab) to study long-lived hadrons forming in nuclei.  To select the events from the E02-104 experiment at JLab, the data mining software, developed at Old Dominion University, efficiently skims the existing data files and copies the output over the network directly to the CMENP group offsite. The hadrons studied by our collaborators are pions, kaons, protons, and hyperons. The analysis by this group of the omega and f1 mesons and will investigate the mass dependence of hadronization.  These results are essential for the interpretation of jet-quenching and proton-nucleus collisions at RHIC and the LHC as well as neutrino interactions with nuclei at energies of a few GeV.  This project will be extended to CLAS12.  The PCAL software of CLAS12 is needed for the identification of a neutral pion, which exists in the decay of both the omega and f1 mesons.  The CMENP group has taken the lead on PCAL software development.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is a successful theory of the strong nuclear interaction.  It can describe how protons and neutrons in the atomic nucleus are built from smaller particles called quarks.  QCD also explains how quarks combine to form other particles.  Three quarks bound together form baryons. Protons and neutrons are the most well-known baryons.   A meson is a type of particle made from a quark and an antimatter quark.  At low energies, quark have a unique feature called confinement, where quarks do not travel freely but are always bound together.   If a quark is extracted from a baryon or meson, the energy in the binding creates a quark-antiquark pair from the vacuum leading to meson production.  However, nature is more complicated with the quarks swirling around for some time before coalescing into mesons and baryons.  Figure 1 shows the propagation time (quarks moving freely) and the formation time (quarks combining to form particles).

At Canisius College, Dr. Michael Wood and his undergraduate students studied the formation of the omega meson.  The omega meson contains a mixture of up and down quarks and their antimatter counterparts.  It is similar to the smallest meson, the pion, but with 5 times the mass.    The students analyzed data from the E02-104  experiment collected in Hall B at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (TJNAF), that is a Department of Energy national laboratory in Newport News, VA.  The experiment employed the 6-GeV electron beam that was scattered off of targets of deuterium, carbon, iron, and lead.  The various nuclei are used as a ruler; the larger the nucleus, the more material the quarks may interact with on their journey,  and the more information to reconstruct the process of formation.  This project is the first to study the formation of the omega meson. 

The students filtered the many terabytes of data to isolate the events with a possible omega meson.  These events contained the scattered electron and 3 pions, which is the prominent decay of the omega meson.  With the filtered data, they reconstructed the mass from the 3 pions to search for possible omega mesons.  Figure 2 shows a narrow peak that are the omega mesons.  Instead of determining the mass from the conversation of energy and momentum, the students used another technique developed at CERN.  This technique used the differences in the reconstructed masses to improve the separation of the meson peak from the background.  The next step in their analysis is to remove the background from the distribution.

To understand the background, the students simulated all possible particle reactions, at the energy of the experiment, that produce 3 pions.  They used a computer model with our current knowledge of particle reactions to produce the events.  The generated events were put through a realistic model of the detector system in Hall B.  Corrections to the number of produced omega mesons were calculated from the output of the simulations.  Figure 3 shows the correction faction with respect to target nucleus.  The results are as expected with a fairly constant correction.  The small value of 1% indicates that production of omega mesons is a rare process.

Canisius College is a small, liberal-arts institution in Buffalo, NY.  The college sets a high priority of involving undergraduate students in original research.  This project was an analysis so the students learned about mining large data sets, particle kinematics, displaying data graphically, and subtracting background.  They wrote their own programs to read in the Hall B data, select the decay particles, apply cuts to identify the omega mesons, and produce plots to display the data.  They learned how to model a particle reaction with the simulations and calculate correction factors.  Both the data filtering and the simulations required handling big data.  The students worked with the software container system, Docker, to make the computations run seamlessly.  These are skills to are highly sought after by graduate programs and employers.

Every summer, the students visited TJNAF with Dr. Wood when he attended the collaboration meetings.  These trips to the lab made the greatest impact with the students.  They spoke with staff scientists, graduate students, and collaborators, both international and domestic.  In addition, they toured the lab and had the opportunity to see in person the large detectors needed to reconstruct the subatomic particles.  This grant was successful at being the first to analyze the formation of the omega meson.  Just as successful has been the training of the undergraduate students.
